posts.title: L’Amour, l’argent, l’amour
posts.excerpt: L’Amour, L’Argent, L’Amour (2000) was a hit in Germany this year, with the press praising everything from the actors to the director and plot. The titles were initially alluring, red and intercut with time-lapse firework flashes of a city on New Year’s Eve. Helped by a restless camera, the viewer soon realises that it isn’t …

posts._title: Sharunas Bartas – A Casa aka The House (1997)
posts.title: A Casa
posts.excerpt: Quote: The House was reviewed a little less favorably than Bartas’ earlier films (regular cinemagoers having given up long ago), but personally I found it his most beautiful film yet. Bartas does tend to repeat himself, it’s true. Reviewers love his grim shadowscapes, shot in B/W, of anonymous, more or less lonely, drunk or disheveled …

posts._title: Zbynek Brynych & Jerzy Skolimowski & Peter Solan – Dialóg 20-40-60 (1968)
posts.title: Dialóg 20-40-60
posts.excerpt: SYNOPSIS: This film is an experiment. One dialogue, three filmmakers, three stories. Jerzy Skolimowski (Polish), Peter Solan (Slovak), and Zbynek Brynych (Czech) created their variations of the same conversation. Focusing on couples in their twenties, forties, and sixties, these three inventive sketches illustrate the emotional interaction between a man and a woman.
posts.director: Zbynek Brynych & Jerzy Skolimowski & Peter Solan

posts.title: Nahota
posts.excerpt: A young convict gets a few days off after a suicide attempt, so that he may regain his strength. He heads back to places closely linked to his youth, during which he gets acquainted with a lonely village teacher…. This film with the lead star Petr Čepek could not be shown in cinemas before the …

posts._title: Paul Grau – Sechs Schwedinnen auf der Alm AKA Six Swedes in the Alps (1983)
posts.title: Sechs Schwedinnen auf der Alm
posts.excerpt: Quote: This comedy has everyone’s favorite 6 Swedish gals enjoying their stay in the alps. When the girls aren’t enjoying the pleasure of their own company they’re out having a good time with nearly everyone else in town.

posts.excerpt: Quote: This title has been extremely rare worldwide and is one of the most highly sought movies! After a woman has been found by the police she desperately tells her story of being kidnapped, drugged and tortured by Princess Arminda (Lina Romay). For years the police have been trying to shut down Arminda’s sex palace …
